bbc;Coronavirus: 'Low confidence' over arrival of PPE from Turkey;"Image copyright Getty Images
There is ""relatively low confidence"" a delayed delivery of 400
column2: 000 protective gowns will arrive on Monday
column3: a senior NHS figure has said.

column1: The consignment had been expected to arrive from Turkey on Sunday.
Chris Hopson
column2: chief executive of NHS Providers
column3: told the BBC there was ""no doubt"" some hospital trusts already had shortages of the gowns
column4: which protect those treating coronavirus patients.

column1: A minister said he was ""hopeful"" the Turkish flight would leave on Monday.
Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said the government was ""working very hard"" to resolve the issue but added there had been ""challenges at the Turkish end"".
I don't want to start making more and more promises but I understand that flight will take off this afternoon and those [gowns] will be delivered
column2: he told BBC Breakfast.

column1: Another 25 million gowns from China had also been procured and the UK would be ""getting those shortly as well""
column2: he added.

column1: Downing Street said the government had now delivered a billion pieces of personal protective equipment (PPE) to frontline staff.
The prime minister's spokesman said delivery of gowns in particular was ""pressured at the moment"" and there was a ""global supply problem"".
He said the government was working to ensure the shipment is ""delivered as soon as it is ready"" but it was not only reliant on Turkey and had ""plenty more orders lined up and expected"".
First Minister Nicola Sturgeon said Scotland currently had ""adequate stocks"" of all the main items of PPE but gowns were one of the items ""under most pressure"".
Mr Hopson
column2: whose organisation represents healthcare trusts across England
column3: said if the delayed consignment from Turkey did arrive on Monday it would ""probably arrive very late on in the day"".

column1: It just illustrates that we need to be careful about focusing on individual consignments
column2: he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

column1: Bitter experience over the last few weeks has shown until a consignment of gowns has actually landed - that the boxes have been checked and the equipment's been tested - the NHS simply can't count on the gowns being available at the front line.""
Mr Hopson gave the example of an expected consignment of 200
column2: 000 gowns from China which actually only contained 20
column3: 000 gowns when it arrived last week.

column1: Mr Hopson added that while the 400
column2: 000 gowns from Turkey would be welcome
column3: NHS staff were getting through approximately 150
column4: 000 gowns a day.

column1: What we really need to get to is from the current rather hand-to-mouth approach to where sustainable supplies consistently and reliably arrive
column2: he said.

column1: The delay to the consignment is a real worry
column2: both in the short and long-term.

column1: It is clear the pandemic stocks we have been largely relying on to date are running out
column2: at least in terms of gowns and visors.

column1: It has left us depending on international supply - certainly for gowns - as we do not seem to be able to manufacture them ourselves.
Given the international demand for them
column2: this threatens to be an on-going issue that could cause problems for months to come.

column1: Staff are understandably worried - they are putting their lives at risk.
Ministers and their officials are clearly working hard to do what they can.
But in the future
column2: serious questions will need to be asked about why this situation has arisen in the first place.

column1: The NHS Confederation
column2: which represents organisations across healthcare
column3: said delays on the shipment from Turkey make ""a difficult situation worse"".

column1: Its chief executive Niall Dickson said ""it would have been better had the government not made the announcement in the first place"" regarding the order.
Public Health England changed its advice on Friday to allow the NHS to re-use gowns if stock was running low
column2: saying ""some compromise"" was needed ""in times of extreme shortages"".

column1: Mr Hopson said some trusts had taken to washing fluid-repellent gowns at 60C and had found
column2: when washed a maximum three times
column3: they remained resistant.

column2: who runs a healthcare service in Hampshire providing care to people in their own homes
column3: said PPE is the ""biggest challenge"" her organisation faces.

column1: She said she is struggling to get hold of enough masks and some staff had resigned because they didn't feel safe with the protective equipment available.
We're going into people's houses who might have Covid but we don't have anything to protect ourselves except perhaps a little plastic apron and gloves

column1: Sir Richard Branson has warned that airline Virgin Atlantic needs government support to survive.
The boss of the Virgin Group said he was not asking for a handout
column2: but a commercial loan
column3: believed to be £500m.

column1: In an open letter to staff
column2: Sir Richard said: ""Many airlines around the world need government support and many have already received it.

column1: The plea comes as Virgin Australia
column2: the country's second largest airline
column3: faces going into administration without aid.

column1: Sir Richard wrote in his letter that without UK government support for Virgin Atlantic ""there won't be any competition left and hundreds of thousands more jobs will be lost"".
Virgin Atlantic - which is owned jointly by Sir Richard and US carrier Delta - has reportedly asked for £500m in aid. However
column2: according to an FT report last week
column3: the request has been rejected by the Treasury.

column1: It said the airline had not done enough to show it had explored other options to bolster cash before asking for state aid.
Government support
In his letter to staff
column2: Sir Richard said: ""We will do everything we can to keep the airline [Virgin Atlantic] going - but we will need government support to achieve that in the face of the severe uncertainty surrounding travel today and not knowing how long the planes will be grounded for.

column1: This would be in the form of a commercial loan - it wouldn't be free money and the airline would pay it back (as EasyJet will do for the £600m loan the government recently gave them).""
He pointed out that Virgin Atlantic started with one plane 36 years ago
column2: before adding: ""Over those years it has created real competition for British Airways
column3: which must remain fierce for the benefit of our wonderful customers and the public at large.""

column1: He also said that he would use his luxury private Carribean island Necker as collateral to raise funds to save jobs at his businesses.
Sir Richard offered to inject £250m into the Virgin Group last month
column2: with most of that going to the airline.

column1: Earlier this month
column2: Rolls-Royce
column3: Airbus
column4: Heathrow airport and Manchester Airports Group sent letters to the government highlighting the importance of Virgin Atlantic to the UK's manufacturing supply chain.

column1: Australia struggles
Meanwhile
column2: it has been reported that Virgin Australia - in which Sir Richard holds a stake of around 10% - is close to going into administration after being refused help by the Australian government.

column1: The carrier has been forced to cancel nearly all of its flights during the coronavirus crisis and been unable to restructure its debts.
The Australian government refused a request from the company for a A$1.4bn (£720m) loan.
The airline - which employs about 16
column2: 000 - is part-owned by Sir Richard along with Etihad
column3: Singapore Airlines and China's HNA.

column1: The brilliant Virgin Australia team is fighting to survive and need support to get through this catastrophic global crisis
column2: Sir Richard said.

column1: We are hopeful that Virgin Australia can emerge stronger than ever
column2: as a more sustainable
column3: financially viable airline.""

column1: He warned: ""If Virgin Australia disappears
column2: Qantas would effectively have a monopoly of the Australian skies. We all know what that would lead to.""

column1: Image copyright Getty Images
Sir Richard also addressed the fierce criticism he has faced in recent weeks over his tax situation.
Critics have pointed out he has paid no UK income tax since moving to the tax-free British Virgin Islands 14 years ago.
Sir Richard is the 312th richest person in the world with an estimated $5.2bn fortune
column2: according to the Bloomberg billionaires index.

column1: I've seen lots of comments about my net worth - but that is calculated on the value of Virgin businesses around the world before this crisis
column2: not sitting as cash in a bank account ready to withdraw
column3: he said.

column1: Over the years significant profits have never been taken out of the Virgin Group
column2: instead they have been reinvested in building businesses that create value and opportunities.""

column1: Turning to the question of living abroad he said: ""Joan and I did not leave Britain for tax reasons but for our love of the beautiful British Virgin Islands (BVI) and in particular Necker Island
column2: which I bought when I was 29 years old
column3: as an uninhabited island on the edges of the BVI.

column1: Over time
column2: we built our family home here. The rest of the island is run as a business
column3: which employs 175 people.""";https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-52354865;2020-04-20T15:17:26

That was the way she was

Kathryn MacLennan said her ""incredible"" grandmother was ""very aware"" of the risks posed by coronavirus but ""she could never imagine leaving her work family"".
She said Mrs Tapley started her career as a nurse after her children had grown up.
She loved her job
column2: in some ways it's horrible that it's happened but also it's nice for us all to know that she died doing the thing she loved

column4: who is from Didcot.

We always said she would outlive all of us with the energy she had and it is tragic her life has been cut short

column1: She still had an awful lot to give.""

We always knew she was a very special

column1: theguardian;Air pollution may be ‘key contributor’ to Covid-19 deaths – study;"High levels of air pollution may be “one of the most important contributors” to deaths from Covid-19
column2: according to research.

column1: The analysis shows that of the coronavirus deaths across 66 administrative regions in Italy
column2: Spain
column3: France and Germany
column4: 78% of them occurred in just five regions
column5: and these were the most polluted.

column1: The research examined levels of nitrogen dioxide
column2: a pollutant produced mostly by diesel vehicles
column3: and weather conditions that can prevent dirty air from dispersing away from a city. Many studies have linked NO 2 exposure to health damage
column4: and particularly lung disease
column5: which could make people more likely to die if they contract Covid-19.

column1: “The results indicate that long-term exposure to this pollutant may be one of the most important contributors to fatality caused by the Covid-19 virus in these regions and maybe across the whole world
column2: ” said Yaron Ogen
column3: at Martin Luther University Halle-Wittenberg in Germany
column4: who conducted the research. “Poisoning our environment means poisoning our own body
column5: and when it experiences chronic respiratory stress its ability to defend itself from infections is limited.”

column1: The analysis is only able to show a strong correlation
column2: not a causal link. “It is now necessary to examine whether the presence of an initial inflammatory condition is related to the response of the immune system to the coronavirus
column3: ” Ogen said.

column1: A separate study published on 7 April looked at fine particle pollution in the US and found that even small increases in levels in the years before the pandemic were associated with far higher Covid-19 death rates. Another recent paper noted that the high death rates seen in the north of Italy correlated with the highest levels of air pollution.
The new research
column2: published in the journal Science of the Total Environment
column3: compared NO 2 levels in January and February in 66 administrative regions with Covid-19 deaths recorded up to 19 March. Ogen also assessed the atmospheric conditions to see where pollution was being trapped over the regions.

column1: He found that 78% of the 4
column2: 443 deaths were in four regions in northern Italy and one around Madrid in Spain. These five regions had the worst combination of NO 2 levels and airflow conditions that prevented dispersal of air pollution.

column1: Ogen noted that the Po Valley in Italy and Madrid were surrounded by mountains
column2: which helps trap pollution
column3: as is Hubei province in China
column4: where the pandemic began. “However
column5: my research is only an initial indication that there might be a correlation between the level of air pollution
column6: air movement and the severity of the course of the corona outbreaks

column1: Prof Jonathan Grigg
column2: from Queen Mary University of London
column3: said the study showed an association between Covid-19 deaths and NO 2 levels. “This association could reflect a causal link between exposure to air pollution and increased vulnerability to fatal Covid infection
column4: but other factors cannot be ruled out at this stage. For example
column5: the study does not adjust for differences in age distribution in different areas.”

column1: Widespread lockdowns around the world have led to reduced vehicle traffic and air pollution. However
column2: long-term exposure to dirty air before the pandemic may be more important than current levels of pollution.

column1: In the UK
column2: NO 2 has been at illegal levels in most urban areas for the last decade. A key policy to reduce NO 2 levels is the introduction of clean air zones
column3: where charges are imposed to deter the most polluting vehicles from city centres. But the introduction of some CAZs has been postponed because of the coronavirus crisis.

column1: Jenny Bates
column2: an air pollution campaigner at Friends of the Earth
column3: said: “This new study is worrying. We know NO 2 is a toxic gas that inflames the lining of the lungs and reduces immunity to lung infections
column4: so it may not be surprising that people who have suffered in areas with high levels of NO 2 could be more susceptible to coronavirus.

column1: “This is all the more reason to keep traffic and pollution levels down as much as possible now and get out of this terrible situation with a view to fewer but cleaner vehicles on the road.”";https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2020/apr/20/air-pollution-may-be-key-contributor-to-covid-19-deaths-study;2020-04-20T13:17:48
theguardian;On the frontline: meet the NHS workers tackling coronavirus;"“We’re used to death – death is part of life in intensive care – but not in the kind of numbers that we’re seeing
column2: and that’s really quite hard to take
column3: ” says Tom Billyard
column4: a consultant at University Hospitals Coventry and Warwickshire
column5: as he reflects on the unprecedented challenges of the Covid-19 pandemic.

column1: In preparation for his latest 12-hour shift in ITU
column2: where the worst affected patients are given life support
column3: Billyard begins to don several layers of personal protective equipment (PPE) over his blue scrubs.

column1: First a pair of latex gloves
column2: then a surgical hat. Next a full-length gown tied together at the rear
column3: followed by an additional pair of latex gloves which are meticulously taped on to the sleeves for extra security.

column1: Finally
column2: an FFP3 mask
column3: which grips his face so tightly it will leave red marks across his cheeks
column4: and a yellow-rimmed plastic visor to provide a secondary barrier against the disease.

column1: “I feel trepidation
column2: ” he says softly
column3: before entering. “There’s a load of patients in there and I don’t know if they’re going to survive this.”

column1: Tom Billyard
column2: a consultant at UHCW. Roger Townsend
column3: clinical lead for intensive care. All photographs by Jonny Weeks.

column1: Struggling for breath
Billyard is one of more than 9
column2: 000 employees at the hospital
column3: all of whom – porters and nurses
column4: cleaners and chaplains
column5: consultants and volunteers – have a vital role to play in the treatment of patients and the functioning of the hospital.

column1: Emily Jones
column2: a senior sister in the emergency department (ED)
column3: works on the hospital’s frontline. “ED is usually quite noisy
column4: ” she says. “But that’s not the case now – you don’t see the patients immediately
column5: until you look through the curtains
column6: and then you realise quite how unwell they can be.

column1: “We’ve had everything from patients who have self-presented at the door saying: ‘I’ve had a cough for a few days
column2: ’ to people who have walked up the stairs to get to the emergency department and can barely hold a sentence with you. We’re also getting crews bringing in patients of various ages who are struggling to get breaths while they’re on oxygen.”

column1: The West Midlands is one of the UK’s most affected regions. At the time of writing
column2: UCHW has admitted 568 patients with Covid-19 and recorded 161 deaths from it
column3: while 316 patients have been discharged after making full recoveries. It has transferred its minor injuries unit to a neighbouring hospital
column4: allowing it to prioritise the influx of Covid-19 patients.

column1: “Wow
column2: ” Jones says
column3: pausing at the severity of the symptoms she’s treating. “The acuity of our patients has gone up so much. They are so much sicker than we previously saw.”

column1: A blizzard of healthcare staff whirls around her – some reading patient notes
column2: others making telephone calls
column3: washing hands
column4: cleaning everything in sight and
column5: heartbreakingly
column6: placing a picture of a dove on to the door of one of the patients.

column1: “That’s to show they’re on the end-of-life care pathway
column2: ” a nurse explains. “It means we should give them peace.”

column1: Patients and staff in the emergency department.
Isolation
Patients who present with less life-threatening difficulties are often transferred to the respiratory wards on level three for round-the-clock care. There
column2: the eerie silence continues. With no families visiting and the corridors all but empty
column3: it feels like a ghost hospital.

column1: UHCW currently has 84 Covid-positive patients
column2: 12 of whom are in ITU
column3: with 72 designated “query Covid” who are yet to be tested. Some lie in isolation rooms
column4: texting friends and loved ones
column5: others in wards of six beds; many seem in a state of shock and weariness
column6: barely registering the world around them.

column1: Patients and staff on wards 30
Mark Anders
column2: a local paramedic
column3: was himself struck down by Covid-19. “We all joked about going to emergency coughs and high temperatures
column4: because that’s all we were going to.”

column1: He fell ill during a Saturday night shift. “I got halfway through the shift and I said to my crew mate: ‘I don’t know what it is; I just don’t feel right
column2: ’” he says.

column1: “Then I got home and the temperature started. I had a week at home of self-isolating
column2: looking after myself
column3: taking paracetamol every four hours
column4: fluids
column5: just trying to do everything to keep my temperature down. After a week I couldn’t control it. From there on: nightmare.”

column1: Anders was lucky. As doctors readied him for transfer to ITU
column2: his body began to fight back. Sitting in his pyjamas and still bearing bloody scars around his septum from the oxygen supply that kept him alive
column3: he has been told he can soon return home to his family.

column1: “Massive
column2: ” he says
column3: when asked about the value of the NHS. “It’s the first time I’ve been this ill in my life. They have been brilliant.”

column1: Mark Anders
column2: a paramedic who caught Covid-19
column3: receives the thumbs up from a nurse.

column1: Frightened
The first case of Covid-19 in Coventry was on ward 50
column2: the renal ward. Lakhbir Kaur
column3: known to her colleagues as Lacky
column4: has been a sister there for five years. She treated Coventry’s “patient zero” and has watched with concern as the virus has spread through the local community. She fears that it may also transition from patients to staff.

column1: For much of her shift
column2: she wears only an apron
column3: gloves and surgical mask – the kind you would find in a dentist’s surgery.

column1: “It’s scary
column2: ” she says. “Our masks already have an expiry date on them and the NHS have covered up the existing expiry date with a further expiry date. What is that? Are they hiding something or are they legitimately tested?

column1: “Infection control have said they have been retested [and are fit for purpose] for another 10 years. I’m wary about that. I really am. I’m a single parent – I’ve got a daughter. She’s the thing I live for. The thought of taking this home from work to her freaks me out.”
A close-up of the cracked skin on her hands caused by washing them so frequently.
UHCW follows guidance on PPE requirements from Public Health England
column2: the government body.

column1: Fiona Wells
column2: who works in infection prevention control
column3: is one of those responsible for dispensing and teaching safe use of PPE. “PPE is an extremely emotive topic
column4: ” she says. “People are very frightened about the possibility that it might not be enough.

column1: “Some of the images we see [from abroad] show people dressed up in hazard suits … and it adds to the tension around PPE. But it comes back to the key question: what is necessary? And then using it appropriately.”
Each procedure and each ward might require different levels of protection. In ITU patients might undergo aerosol procedures

column1: Halfway up Mount Everest
Back in the dimly lit corridors surrounding ITU
column2: nurses and consultants prepare to enter the highly infectious wards. Just like Billyard before them
column3: they too must don – and later doff – every piece of equipment with the utmost precision

column5: the safe zones and future patients is extreme.

column1: Yellow and black hazard tape marks the flooring – tread on the wrong side of it and you will be quickly admonished – and white plastic sheets with red zippers seal the outer perimeter of the changing zone.

Each person who enters ITU is likely to stay inside for three hours or more before they take a 20-minute break. The sweat caused by wearing so much plastic is instantaneous and the FFP3 masks irritate the nose and skin. Yet there can be no distractions in critical care
column2: where half of all patients with Covid-19 will not survive.

column1: faz;Tom Tugendhat and Norbert Röttgen want a Friendship-Treaty;"Brexit marks the chance for a new beginning. The chairmen of the Foreign Affairs Comittes of the Bundestag and the House of Commons make the case for a German-British Friendship Treaty. A guest column.
EU-Supporters gather on Brexit-Day in front of the British Embassy in Berlin Bild: EPA
More than three years after the referendum
column2: Brexit on Saturday became reality as the United Kingdom formally left the European Union. After 40 years of European integration and being an integral part of a community as tightly intertwined as the EU
column3: this departure not only fundamentally changes the relationship between the United Kingdom and the EU. It also requires us to rethink the bilateral relations between EU member states and the UK. While we have different perspectives on Brexit
column4: we agree that it is now time to move on.

column1: Many aspects of our future relationship will be organized at the European level as part of the ongoing Brexit negotiations. But some issues are bilateral and require stronger direct ties. We think it’s time for a German-British Friendship Treaty
column2: which regulates enhanced cooperation and strengthens our shared values
column3: cultural and educational policy and
column4: yes
column5: our foreign affairs. A treaty would complement whatever the UK agreed with the 27 member states and deepen our bonds.

column1: One of the first consequences of Brexit will be that officials
column2: ministers and parliamentarians from our two countries will no longer regularly meet in Brussels. We need to make sure understanding remains strong and encourage exchanges between us. Ramping up our embassy staff and the cultural and educational programmes run by institutions such as the Goethe Institute
column3: the British Council or the German Academic Exchange Service can also change the tone.

column1: Irrespective of the UK’s decision on remaining a full member of the Erasmus exchange programme after 2020
column2: we should strengthen direct ties between German and British students and teachers and deepen scientific cooperation between our researchers. Creating new bilateral grants to fund joint projects no longer eligible for EU funding would promote collaboration and could culminate in shared clusters of excellence at German and British universities.

column1: Shared enterprise will boost much more than science and the economy
column2: it will further entwine our values. Germany and the United Kingdom are home to some of the most tolerant and open societies in the world. And yet racism in general
column3: and anti-Semitism in particular
column4: are on the rise in our societies. To counter this we should launch a joint
column5: high profile project that fights intolerance and promotes solidarity.

column1: For different reasons
column2: taking a strong stance against anti-Semitism has particular importance for both societies: to Germans it is central to our historical responsibility for the horrors of the Second World War; to Britons forcefully condemning anti-Semitism it is a recognition of the proud history the UK has of providing refuge to Jews fleeing from prosecution and death in Nazi Germany. As important allies of Israel and on the 75th anniversary of the liberation of Auschwitz
column3: the time to act is now.

column1: Finally
column2: Germany and the United Kingdom have shared interests overseas. Our two countries stood together on every major international issue
column3: from global trade to the Iran nuclear deal. We both recognise that we share a continent
column4: values
column5: making our security indivisible. Geography and geopolitics is not changed by Brexit. For both of us
column6: security in the Middle East has direct implications for the stability of our own societies
column7: and those of our neighbours. As part of a wider initiative
column9: or within the E3 format alongside France
column10: Germany and the UK will no doubt cooperate in political and military engagements in the region
column12: to helping to support parties trying to bring peace to Libya.

column1: With Britain’s EU membership coming to an end it is time to look ahead and to create a strong foundation for our future bilateral relations. A German-British Friendship Treaty would provide a framework. column1: I am here

column5: this place

column1: Auschwitz is like a scar from a terrible trauma. It never goes away and the pain never stops. I have always wondered
column2: if I had been born in Hungary
column3: where my grandparents were from
column4: instead of New York in February

column1: The answer is: no.
I would have been one of the 438

column1: 75 years ago today
column2: when Soviet troops entered these gates

column1: We have all wondered how an advanced country that gave the world great literature and art and scientific advancement

column4: a depravity like Auschwitz.

column1: I’m afraid Auschwitz offers more questions than answers.
But let me be clear: While Germany and Austria caused
column2: created and carried out this shattering evil practically every other European country helped the Nazis gather up their Jewish citizens. Too many people in too many countries made Auschwitz happen.

column1: And when European Jews begged the world for a safe harbor
column2: someplace to go

column1: Even my own country - the beacon of freedom - turned out its light on the jewish people when they needed it the most.

column1: And again

column1: Hitler tested the world. And at every step he saw the truth: the world did not care. That’s when he knew that he could build this factory of death.
Evian led to Auschwitz. Kristallnacht led to Auschwitz. World Anti-Semitism led to Auschwitz.

column1: faz;Facebook: Splitting up is not the solution;"The biggest disadvantage for European tech companies compared to their Chinese and American competitors is the absence of a large-scale domestic market. A guest contribution.
Everybody agrees that the internet needs new rules – from those governing how people’s private data is handled
column2: or how the integrity of elections is preserved
column3: to the mechanisms for allowing data to flow between companies and nation states or how harmful content is identified and taken down. These decisions will determine whether the norms and standards of the internet are created on a global level
column4: preserving the open
column5: accessible and universal internet of today
column6: or whether individual countries will diverge further from each other
column7: creating their own rules and systems
column8: turning themselves into walled gardens and ending the universal global internet as we know it.

column1: But we in Europe and the West are not the only ones grappling with decisions about the future of the internet. As we speak
column2: there is a fight for the soul of the internet already underway. In fact
column3: another internet already exists. The Chinese internet – one based on very different values: state control; censorship; and surveillance. And some other countries
column4: to greater or lesser degrees
column5: are beginning to follow China’s lead.

column1: Europe may not have its own Silicon Valley
column2: or be as advanced in large scale AI as China or the West Coast of the United States
column3: but it is a thought leader when it comes to the future of the internet. GDPR was the first serious attempt to create a set of principles and rules around private data in the digital age. And those principles are at the heart of a vision for the internet that I believe is shared among all open societies: that it is accessible to all; transparent and accountable; that you control your own data; and that competition and innovation should be encouraged.

column1: Facebook wants to add its voice
In the US
column2: the political debate is around whether big tech companies should be broken up. Here
column3: in the EU
column4: it is largely about how tech companies should be better regulated. In both cases
column5: the fundamental question is the same: how can the power of large tech companies be held to account?

column1: Facebook wants to add its voice to this debate in a constructive way. We are not resisting regulation – the opposite
column2: in fact. Regulating the tech sector is a far more effective way to ensure that tech serves the needs of society than simply chopping successful companies into bits. We have not only long accepted the need for new regulation in a host of areas
column3: we are impatient to get going.

column1: It is now time we moved beyond words and towards action. A new EU Commission is in post
column2: a new Parliament has been elected
column3: and a great regulatory challenge lies before us. My message to European policymakers is: Everyone agrees the internet needs new rules. We want them
column4: just as you do. So let’s get to work.

column1: One area where we should work together is data portability. The reason is simple: if we want a competitive
column2: open internet where new services can compete with large platforms like Facebook
column3: we have to enable to people to move their data from one service to a competing one.

column1: You're not giving us your data

It is a subject we have been working on with policymakers in Germany. Last year we held a series of round table discussions hosted by Stiftung Datenschutz and attended by government and industry representatives
column2: privacy experts

column1: faz;Quantum Tech: Future Directions;"These are early days in quantum technologies. It is clear
column2: that this field will have a significant impact on a wide range of economic sectors.

column1: Model of the inside of a quantum computer Bild: Bastian Benrath

We are entering a new era which will catalyze discoveries in science and technology. Novel computing platforms will probe the fundamental laws of our universe and aid in solving hard problems that affect all of us. Machine learning programs powered by specialized chips are already yielding breakthrough after breakthrough.
Quantum computing is part of the larger field of quantum information science (QIS). All three branches of QIS – computation
column2: communication
column3: and sensing – are advancing at rapid rates and a discovery in one area can spur progress in another.

column1: Businesses and investors are now ramping up their interest in these fields. In this piece
column2: we will first outline the various quantum technologies and then cover opportunities and impact. While these are early days in quantum tech
column3: we can see exciting possibilities coming down the road. In the past three years alone
column4: funds invested more than $650 million into quantum tech companies. The quantum tech ecosystem is growing rapidly in many geographies across the globe and is not dominated by just one or two locations.

column1: Quantum communication leverages the unusual properties of quantum systems to transmit information in a manner that no eavesdropper can read. This field is becoming increasingly critical as quantum computing drives us to a post-quantum cryptography regime: quantum computers of sufficient size will be able to break many cryptographic schemes currently in use
column2: which means that new protocols will need to be developed and put into use.

column1: An emerging class of sensors
There are quantum-resistant schemes currently being tested – for example
column2: as part of the NIST process – for which there are no known quantum (or classical
column3: for that matter) attacks. For ultimate security
column4: however
column5: it may be that some will choose to rely on new quantum communication protocols that make use of a new quantum internet. Those protocols will be guaranteed secure by the fundamental laws of physics
column6: but will require new hardware beyond what we currently use for classical data transmission.

column1: Quantum sensing is a robust field of research that uses quantum devices to move beyond classical limits in sensing magnetic and other fields. For example
column2: there is an emerging class of sensors for detecting position
column3: navigation
column4: and timing (PNT) at the atomic scale. These micro-PNT devices can provide highly accurate positioning data when GPS is jammed or unavailable.

column1: Quantum sensors also show promise in the life sciences. Researchers have already demonstrated the use of nanoscale quantum sensors to measure the electromagnetic activity of single cells. We can use these sensors to monitor the firing of neurons and cardiac cells. These technologies can develop into cornerstone diagnostic and therapeutic devices in the future.
The trick is to build such a system

One of the critical differences between quantum and classical computation is that in quantum computing we are manipulating quantum states themselves; this gives us a much larger computing space to work in than in classical computers. In classical computers
column2: if we wish to model a real-world quantum physical we can only do so with representations of such a system and we cannot implement the physics itself. This key difference leads to exciting possibilities for the future of computing and science. All this starts with fundamental truths about our world that were developed during the quantum mechanics revolution in the first half of the 20th century";https://www.faz.net/aktuell/wirtschaft/netzkonferenz-dld/quantum-tech-future-directions-16586824.html;2020-01-19T11:10:00
